gw.api.util

Class XPath

  • java.lang.Object
    • gw.api.util.XPath

  • public class XPath
extends java.lang.Object
    Used to manipulate an XML document using XPath syntax. Can be used to get, set, remove and copy elements or sub trees within the original XML document.

    An XPath object can be created from an XML string, for example: 

       var xpath = new gw.api.util.XPath("<RootElement/>")
    Author:
    tmorris

    • Constructor Detail

      • XPath

        public XPath(java.lang.String xml)
      throws org.xml.sax.SAXException
        Parses the given XML string and creates an XPath object for manipulating it.

        You cannot create a completely empty XPath object but you can create just the root element, for example: new gw.api.util.XPath("<MyRoot/>"). You can then add attributes and sub elements to the root.

        All operations are relative to the root element of the XML. So if you started with <MyRoot> and then set the path "/Sub" to "C" this would create a "Sub" element under "MyRoot" with contents "C".

        Parameters:
        xml - the XML to be parsed
        Throws:
        org.xml.sax.SAXException - if the XML is incorrect and cannot be parsed

      • XPath

        public XPath(org.w3c.dom.Document xml)
        Creates an XPath object for manipulating the given XML document.

        All operations are relative to the root element of the XML. So if you started with <MyRoot> and then set the path "/Sub" to "C" this would create a "Sub" element under "MyRoot" with contents "C".

        Parameters:
        xml - the XML document to be manipulated
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if the XML document has no root element

      • XPath

        public XPath(org.w3c.dom.Element element)
        Creates an XPath object for manipulating the given XML element.

        All operations are relative to this element. So if you started with <MyElement> and then set the path "/Sub" to "C" this would create a "Sub" element under "MyElement" with contents "C".

        Parameters:
        element - the XML element to be manipulated

    • Method Detail

      • getDocument

        public org.w3c.dom.Document getDocument()
        Return the XML document being manipulated by this XPath
        Returns:
        the XML document being manipulated

      • get

        public java.lang.String get(java.lang.String path)
        Get the value of the given path as a string. If the path resolves to an element then the result is the concatenation of all text within the element. If it resolves to an attribute then the result is the value of the attribute. For example, given 
           <A attr='x'>
     <B>B1</B>
     <B id='id2'>B2<C>C1</C></B>
   </A>
        Then
        • get("/@attr") == "x"
        • get("/B") == "B1"
        • get("/B[2]") == "B2C1"
        • get("/B[2]/C") == "C1"
        • get("/B[2]/@id") == "id2"
        • get("/B/@id") == "id2" (only the second B has an id attribute so this is unambiguous)
        • get("/X") == null
        Note that A is not mentioned because it is the root node. The modifier [n] can be used to pick out a particular element if there are multiple elements that match, though it is not required if the path is unambiguous.
        Parameters:
        path - the path of the value to get
        Returns:
        the value of the text contents of the specified element or attribute, or null if the path does not match any element or attribute

      • count

        public int count(java.lang.String path)
        Get the number of items which match the given path. For example, given 
           <A attr='x'>
     <B>B1</B>
     <B id='id2'>B2<C>C1</C></B>
   </A>
        Then
        • count("/@attr") == 1
        • count("/B") == 2
        • count("/B[2]") == 1
        • count("/B[2]/C") == 1
        • count("/B[2]/@id") == 1
        • count("/B/@id") == 1
        • count("/X") == 0
        Note that A is not mentioned because it is the root node. The modifier [n] can be used to pick out a particular element if there are multiple elements that match, though it is not required if the path is unambiguous.
        Parameters:
        path - the path to match.
        Returns:
        the number of items which match the path or zero if it does not match anything

      • set

        public void set(java.lang.String path,
                java.lang.String value)
        Set the string value of the item with the given path. If elements of the path do not yet exist then create them. For example, given 
           <A/>
        the calls set("/B/C", "X") and set("/B/@id", "id") will create the following: 
           <A>
     <B id='id'><C>X</C></B>
   </A>
        The modifiers [n] (where n is a number) and [before(element)] or [after(element)] can be used to specify exactly where new elements should be added. For example, given: 
           <A>
     <B>B</B>
     <B>B2</B>
     <C>C</C>
   </A>
        The call set("/B[3][before(C)]", "B3") will produce: 
           <A>
     <B>B</B>
     <B>B2</B>
     <B>B3</B>
     <C>C</C>
   </A>
        Parameters:
        path - the path of the item whose string value is to be set.
        value - the string value to be set

      • set

        public void set(java.lang.String path,
                XPath value)
        Overwrite the XML tree at the given path with the given XML tree. If elements of the path do not yet exist then create them. For example, given 
           <A/>
        the call set("/B", new gw.api.util.XPath("<B id='id1'><C>X</C></B>")) will create the following: 
           <A>
     <B id='id1'><C>X</C></B>
   </A>
        Subsequently calling set("/B", new gw.api.util.XPath("<B id='id2'><C>Y</C></B>")) will overwrite the previous values, giving: 
           <A>
     <B id='id2'><C>Y</C></B>
   </A>
        Note that the last element in the path (B in the examples above) must always match the root element of the XPath XML tree in "value". If it is not this method will throw IllegalArgumentException.

        Together with copy(java.lang.String) and remove(java.lang.String), this method can be used to move a sub tree within an XML tree. For example, to get from: 

           <A>
     <B>B</B>
     <B id='id1'><Y id='id2'>New</Y></B>
     <B>B2</B>
     <C>C</C>
   </A>
        to: 
           <A>
     <B>B</B>
     <B>B2</B>
     <B id='id1'><Y id='id2'>New</Y></B>
     <C>C</C>
   </A>
        You could use the sequence: 
           var subTree = xPath.copy("/B[2]");
   xPath.remove("/B[2]");
   xPath.set("/B[3][before(C)]", subTree);
        Parameters:
        path - the path of the item whose value is to be set.
        value - the XML tree value to be set
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if the root node of the given value does not match the last element of the given path

      • remove

        public void remove(java.lang.String path)
        Remove the first item that matches the given path. If the path matches the root of a sub tree then the whole sub tree is removed. For example, given 
           <A>
     <B id='id1'><C>X</C></B>
     <B id='id2'><C>Y</C></B>
   </A>
        Then remove("/B") will result in: 
           <A>
     <B id='id2'><C>Y</C></B>
   </A>
        To remove all elements that match a given path use: 
           while (xPath.count("/B") > 0) {
     xPath.remove("/B");
   }
        This method does nothing if the path does not match any elements
        Parameters:
        path - the path of the element or sub tree to be removed

      • copy

        public XPath copy(java.lang.String path)
        Make a copy of the element at the given path and return it as a new XPath object. If the path matches the root of a sub tree then the whole sub tree is copied. For example, given 
           <A>
     <B id='id1'><C>X</C></B>
     <B id='id2'><C>Y</C></B>
   </A>
        Then copy("/B[2]") will result in a new XPath object containing just: 
           <B id='id2'><C>Y</C></B>
        Returns null if the path does not match any item or matches an attribute
        Parameters:
        path - the path of the element or sub tree to be copied
        Returns:
        a new XPath object containing a copy of the element or sub tree

      • toString

        public java.lang.String toString()
        Convert the entire XML document to a string and return it. The string is parseable by any XML parser so new gw.api.util.XPath(xPath.toString()) results in a copy of the original XPath object.
        Overrides:
        toString in class java.lang.Object
        Returns:
        the XML converted to a string
